did.unittitle: Raleigh Coal & Coke Company Rail Spur Drawing 1920
did.abstract: As-built drawing for a railroad spur line to the Raleigh Coal & Coke Company's No. 3 Mine, located on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's Pine Creek Branch (New River District).

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Raleigh Coal & Coal Company Rail Spur Drawing must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Raleigh Coal & Coke Company Rail Spur Drawing, Ms2009-039 - Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Raleigh Coal & Coke Company Rail Spur Drawing was purchased by Special Collections in 2009. The document had been part of a larger group of railroad-related materials compiled by a collector, then sold to a dealer (see "separated material" section).

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing and description of the Raleigh Coal & Coke Company Rail Spur Drawing commenced and was completed in March 2009.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Raleigh Coal & Coke Company operated in West Virginia during the early twentieth century, establishing a mine and camp at Raleigh (Raleigh County) in 1909. The company marketed its coal under the trade name "Black Knight Coal." Raleigh Coal & Coke ceased operations in 1950.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of an as-built drawing for a railroad spur line to the Raleigh Coal & Coke Company's Number 3 Mine. The spur was located on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway's Piney Creek Branch (New River District). The drawing (number X-1614) contains the original plan, executed in 1918, as well as the as-built revisions of 1920.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p:
The Raleigh Coal & Coke Company Rail Spur Drawing was acquired as part of a larger collection of railway-related material that had been compiled by a collector, then sold to a dealer. In the course of processing, the drawing was removed to a separate collection. The acquisition of which this drawing was a part also included:
